   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Fevers: Differential includes RLL fluid collection which is most
   likely source of hypotension.  SVRs and CVP not consistent with septic
   shock, however WBCs with bands today and pt continues to be febrile.
   All blood cultures have been negative to date and LP done yesterday
   showed a negative gram stain with only 1 WBC. Medications can also
   contribute to fever as well as subdural hematomas.
   -follow up cultures- blood, sputum, CSF
   - f/u final Chest CT read, speak with IR regarding drainage
   -follow up BAL cultures from bronch
   -continue linezolid for MRSA VAP
   -send surveillence cultures
   -cooling blanket prn
   -follow fever curve
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim test today
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely etiology is septic shock, although CVP and SVR
   more consistent with cardiogenic shock.  Given overall clinical
   picture, sepsis is most likely etiology.  Pt responded to IV fluids
   without requiring pressors last night.  Lactate 1.2 which may be in the
   setting of volume resuscitated sepsis.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix as needed for diuresis as tolerated by BP
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim test
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed.
   - switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   -lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP
    -f/u BAL
   -nebs and suctioning
   -minimize sedation with propofol/fentanyl
   .
   # Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.
   -appreciate neurology recs
   -f/u final EEG read
   -hold as many sedating medications as possible with daily wake up
   -monitor neuro exams
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Differential includes Tylenol toxicity, medication
   effects, hepatic abscess or early stages of shock liver given
   hypotension and sepsis; however I think this is less likely.
   - RUQ U/S
   - continue to trend LFTs
   .
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   -monitor on tele
   -f/u TSH (was lowish range on admission which was likely sick euthyroid
   related, but if came back undetectable, hyperthyroidism could account
   for tachycardia and even fevers)
   -continue metoprolol and give more prn
   .
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.
   -continue keppra for seizure ppx
   -neurosurgery will let us know how often to follow up CT head for
   surveillence
   .
   # Hyponatremia: now low normal range. Could have SIADH picture from
   subdural hematomas.
   - continue to monitor
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine. Checking TSH as above.
   .
   # HTN: currently normotensive/hypotensive.
   - Lasix, Metoprolol as tolerated by BP
   .
   # FEN: on tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control,
   monitor blood sugars, replete lytes PRN.
   .
   # PPX: heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care, Ranitidine,
   bowel regimen.
   .
   # Access: Lines LSC and aline are new [**2156-12-21**].
   .
   # Code Status: Full
   .
   # Dispo: ICU level of care.
   ICU Care

- Chest CT done with possible fluid collection in the right lower lobe (RLL) per preliminary read.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   .
   # fevers: There are many potential sources for infection. He has a
   right pleural effusion which could be a source, empyema, pneumonia. His
   sputum is growing MRSA. Also has hygromas and residual blood in his
   subdural space, last CT scan suggests right parietal hypodense area
   which could be infectious. Last urinalysis from yesterday was not
   overly convincing for infection; he does not seem to have abdominal
   tenderness or profuse diarrhea to suggest C diff infection. Sinus
   infection also on the differential as is a central process for
   hyperthermia. He did have a bronch today which reportedly was not very
   impressive with only thin secretions but maybe signs of trachitis. All
   blood cultures have been negative to date and LP done yesterday showed
   a negative gram stain with only 1 WBC. His original central line was
   discontinued and left subclavian line was just placed yesterday. He
   also does have an aline in place. Medications can also contribute to
   fever. He was recently on high doses of seroquel, haldol and benzos for
   agitation. They were discontinued yesterday. He is still on reglan,
   zofran and meperidine both of which could contribute to altered mental
   status.
   -follow up cultures- blood, sputum, CSF
   -chest CT to see if effusion is loculated and then may need IP to do
   thoracentesis vs VATS for clean out.
   -follow up BAL from bronch today
   -continue linezolid for MRSA VAP but discontinue aztreonam.
   -send surveillence cultures
   -cooling blanket prn
   -follow fever curve
   .
   # respiratory failure: currently trach in place and on ventilator
   requiring FIO2 of 0.6 with high tital volumes. This could be secondary
   to a MRSA pneumonia. Also concern for the pleural fluid and ? empyema
   contributing. Could also be secondary to altered mental status or even
   a central process given the head bleed. His CXR also suggests fluid
   overload.
   -try a trial of pressure support [**1-28**] and see how he tolerates it
   -lasix gtt for diuresis
   -CT chest as above
   -f/u BAL
   -nebs and suctioning
   -continue sedation for comfort but give trials off sedation
   -continue albuterol/ipratropium
   .
   # mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. He had an LP yesterday which did not
   show any organisms or suggest any meningitis.
   -appreciate neurology recs
   -f/u final EEG read
   -hold as many sedating medications as possible with daily wake up
   -monitor neuro exams
   -d/c reglan, zofran, meperidine
   .
   # tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process. I do not think he is intravascularly dry
   causing tachycardia. Agitation could also contribute.
   -monitor on tele
   -check TSH (was lowish range on admission which was likely sick
   euthyroid related, but if came back undetectable, hyperthyroidism could
   account for tachycardia and even fevers)
   -continue metoprolol and give more prn
   .
   # subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.
   -continue keppra for seizure ppx
   -neurosurgery will let us know how often to follow up CT head for
   surveillence
   .
   # hyponatremia: now low normal range. Could have SIADH picture from
   subdural hematomas. Continue sodium bicarb for now and monitor.
   .
   # hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine. Checking TSH as above.
   .
   # HTN: currently normotensive. continue metoprolol. d/c amlodipine and
   hydralazine for now.
   .
   # FEN: on tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control
   and increase scale for tighter control.
   .
   # PPX: heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care. Lines LSC and
   aline are new [**2156-12-21**].

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. He underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall and has been hospitalized with complications including tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. 

The patient has been experiencing rigors, high fever, and hypotension, which could be signs of infection. His sputum is growing MRSA, and there is a right pleural effusion that could be a source of infection. Additionally, the patient has hygromas and residual blood in his subdural space, suggesting possible infectious etiology. The last urinalysis did not show convincing signs of infection, and there is no evidence of sinus infection or central nervous system infection based on the negative gram stain and low white blood cell count in the cerebrospinal fluid.

The patient is currently on multiple medications that can contribute to fever and altered mental status. Blood cultures have been negative, and the central line has been discontinued. Further follow-up cultures, including blood, sputum, and cerebrospinal fluid, are planned to identify the source of infection. A chest CT will be performed to assess the pleural effusion and determine if thoracentesis or video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) is necessary for cleaning out the effusion.

The patient is also being weaned off sedating medications to assess mental status improvement. The

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Fevers: Differential includes RLL fluid collection which is most
   likely source of hypotension.  SVRs and CVP not consistent with septic
   shock, however WBCs with bands today and pt continues to be febrile.
   All blood cultures have been negative to date and LP done yesterday
   showed a negative gram stain with only 1 WBC. Medications can also
   contribute to fever as well as subdural hematomas.
   -follow up cultures- blood, sputum, CSF
   - f/u final Chest CT read, speak with IR regarding drainage
   -follow up BAL cultures from bronch
   -continue linezolid for MRSA VAP
   -send surveillence cultures
   -cooling blanket prn
   -follow fever curve
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim test today
   .
   # Hypotension: Likely etiology is septic shock, although CVP and SVR
   more consistent with cardiogenic shock.  Given overall clinical
   picture, sepsis is most likely etiology.  Pt responded to IV fluids
   without requiring pressors last night.  Lactate 1.2 which may be in the
   setting of volume resuscitated sepsis.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix as needed for diuresis as tolerated by BP
   - [**Last Name (un) **] stim test
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed.
   - switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   -lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP
    -f/u BAL
   -nebs and suctioning
   -minimize sedation with propofol/fentanyl
   .
   # Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.
   -appreciate neurology recs
   -f/u final EEG read
   -hold as many sedating medications as possible with daily wake up
   -monitor neuro exams
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Differential includes Tylenol toxicity, medication
   effects, hepatic abscess or early stages of shock liver given
   hypotension and sepsis; however I think this is less likely.
   - RUQ U/S
   - continue to trend LFTs
   .
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   -monitor on tele
   -f/u TSH (was lowish range on admission which was likely sick euthyroid
   related, but if came back undetectable, hyperthyroidism could account
   for tachycardia and even fevers)
   -continue metoprolol and give more prn
   .
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.
   -continue keppra for seizure ppx
   -neurosurgery will let us know how often to follow up CT head for
   surveillence
   .
   # Hyponatremia: now low normal range. Could have SIADH picture from
   subdural hematomas.
   - continue to monitor
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine. Checking TSH as above.
   .
   # HTN: currently normotensive/hypotensive.
   - Lasix, Metoprolol as tolerated by BP
   .
   # FEN: on tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control,
   monitor blood sugars, replete lytes PRN.
   .
   # PPX: heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care, Ranitidine,
   bowel regimen.
   .
   # Access: Lines LSC and aline are new [**2156-12-21**].
   .
   # Code Status: Full
   .
   # Dispo: ICU level of care.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism who was admitted for the evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. During hospitalization, he experienced a tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. The patient is currently in the ICU with several medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fevers: The patient has been experiencing fevers, and the differential diagnosis includes a right lower lobe fluid collection, which is likely the source of hypotension. The patient's WBC count with bands suggests an ongoing infection. Blood cultures have been negative, and a lumbar puncture showed a negative gram stain with only one white blood cell. Medications and subdural hematomas can also contribute to fever. Follow-up cultures are needed, and further investigations are required to identify the source of infection.

2. Hypotension: The patient's likely etiology for hypotension is septic shock, although central venous pressure (CVP) and systemic vascular resistance (SVR) are more consistent with cardiogenic shock. The patient responded to intravenous fluids without requiring pressors last night, and lactate levels are within acceptable range. Fluid resuscitation and diuresis as needed for blood pressure management are recommended.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism, who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a fall. He underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, he developed a tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C (99.6°F), heart rate of 118 bpm, blood pressure of 116/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on a tracheostomy tube with CPAP/PSV ventilation. The patient is sedated and on mechanical ventilation.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count with bands, elevated lactate levels, elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST), and other abnormalities in electrolytes and kidney function tests.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Fevers: The patient continues to have fevers, which may be due to a right lower lobe fluid collection, most likely source of hypotension. Blood cultures have been negative, and a lumbar puncture showed no organisms.
   - Follow-up cultures: blood, sputum, CSF
   - Follow up BAL cultures from bronch
   - Continue linezolid for MRSA VAP
   - Send surveillance cultures
   - Cooling blanket as needed
   - Follow fever curve

The patient's TSH level was measured at 5.9. The patient was on pressure support ventilation overnight at a level of 50%. An EEG showed diffuse generalized slowing, with no focal deficits or seizure activity. The patient passed a [Last Name] stim test. The patient's fluid balance is +3.5L. An ultrasound of the liver/gallbladder was conducted. The arterial line was stopped at 02:30 PM and restarted at 03:20 PM.

The patient has allergies to ampicillin and unknown allergens. The last doses of antibiotics administered were vancomycin on 12/22/2015 at 05:00 AM, aztreonam on 12/22/2015 at 04:00 PM, and linezolid on 12/24/2015 at 02:00 AM. The patient is currently receiving infusions of furosemide (Lasix) at a rate of 4 mg/hour, fentanyl at a rate of 200 mcg/hour, and propofol at 50 mcg/kg/min. The patient is also receiving other ICU medications, including heparin sodium for prophylaxis, which was started at 11:49 PM on 12/23/2015. Additionally, the patient is on other medications.

The patient's review of systems remains unchanged from admission except as noted below. The flowsheet data as of 12/24/2015 at 05:04 AM includes vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, and laboratory results. The patient's temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation are within normal ranges. The patient's weight is currently 117.5 kg, with a height of 67 inches. The central venous pressure (CVP) is 20 mmHg. The cardiac output (CO) and cardiac index (CI) are measured at 242.4 L/min and 108.5 L/min/m2 respectively. The mixed venous oxygen saturation is between 96-97%.

The patient has received a total of 4,803 mL of fluids, including 788 mL of total in, 120 mL of PO, 450 mL of TF, 4,023 mL of IVF, and 602 mL of blood products. The patient has also had 1,237 mL of total out, including 340 mL of urine output. The arterial line was stopped at 02:30 PM and restarted at 03:20 PM.

The patient is receiving respiratory support through a tracheostomy

   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Fevers: No clear source, however now afebrile X 24 hours without
   Tylenol, ibuprofen. Bronch showing Staph Aureus, likely MRSA given
   prior sputums with MRSA.  [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim test was appropriate response.
   -follow up cultures- blood, sputum, CSF, BAL
   - Linezolid X 21 days (start date = [**12-22**], end date = [**1-12**])
   -follow fever curve
   .
   # Hypotension: Pt may have had sepsis which is now resolving.
   Medications (Lasix) contributed to low BP.  No pressors necessary.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix as needed for diuresis as tolerated by BP
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed.
   - switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   -lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP
    -f/u BAL
   -nebs and suctioning
   -minimize sedation with propofol/fentanyl, try to wean today
   .
   # Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.  EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both
   cortical and subcortical structures which  may be due to increased
   intracranial pressure, no focal deficits or seizure activity
   -appreciate neurology recs
   -hold as many sedating medications as possible with daily wake up
   -monitor neuro exams
   - Zyprexa 5mg PO TID and wean propofol
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: RUQ U/S normal without hepatic abscess.  Tylenol
   levels negative.  Unclear etiology.  Slightly lower today.
   - continue to trend LFTs
   .
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   -monitor on tele
   -continue metoprolol and give more prn
   .
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.
   -continue keppra for seizure ppx
   -neurosurgery will let us know how often to follow up CT head for
   surveillence
   .
   # Hyponatremia: now low normal range. Could have SIADH picture from
   subdural hematomas.
   - continue to monitor
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine. Checking TSH as above.
   .
   # HTN: currently normotensive/hypotensive.
   - Lasix, Metoprolol as tolerated by BP
   .
   # FEN: on tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control,
   monitor blood sugars, replete lytes PRN.
   .
   # PPX: heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care, Ranitidine,
   bowel regimen.
   .
   # Access: Lines LSC and aline are new [**2156-12-21**].
   .
   # Code Status: Full
   .
   # Dispo: ICU level of care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism who has been admitted to the ICU. The patient underwent an evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall and has since experienced several complications during his hospitalization.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the given information include:

1. Fevers: The patient has had fevers, which may be due to an ongoing infection. Staphylococcus aureus, likely methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), was identified in bronchial secretions. Follow-up cultures are planned to monitor the infection. Linezolid has been prescribed for 21 days.

2. Hypotension: The patient may have had sepsis, which is now resolving. Medications such as Lasix have contributed to low blood pressure. Fluid resuscitation and diuresis as tolerated by blood pressure are recommended.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure, which may be multifactorial including pneumonia (PNA), pulmonary edema, fluid collection, altered mental status, or a central process due to the head bleed. The plan includes weaning from mechanical ventilation, decreasing FiO2 as tolerated, using nebulizers and suctioning, minimizing sedation, and following up with a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL).

4. Mental status: The patient's mental status is

1. Infection: The patient has a history of fevers and respiratory failure, which may indicate an ongoing infection. The bronchoscopy showing Staphylococcus aureus, likely MRSA, further supports the possibility of a bacterial infection. Follow-up cultures are recommended to monitor for any changes in bacterial growth.

2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, with episodes of hypotension. This may be due to sepsis resolving or medication (Lasix) contributing to low blood pressure. Close monitoring and fluid resuscitation as needed are important for managing this condition.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including pneumonia (PNA), pulmonary edema, fluid collection, and possibly secondary to altered mental status or a central process given the head bleed. Weaning from mechanical ventilation by switching to pressure support (PS) and decreasing FiO2 as tolerated is recommended. Diuretics like Lasix may be used for diuresis as tolerated by blood pressure.

4. Mental status changes: The patient's mental status is likely multifactorial, including medications, subdural hematomas, and infection. An EEG showed severe encephalopathy without focal deficits or seizure activity. Minimizing sedating medications with daily wake-up calls and monitoring neuro exams are important.

   [**12-10**] and [**12-11**] for B evacs. Post op course c/b respiratory failure,
   tachycardia, altered mental status, fevers to 103, and probable MRSA
   RLL VAP. Fevers now resolved X 48 hr. Elevated LFTs (trending down)
   and RUQ USG normal. EEG severe encephalopathy. [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim and TSH
   normal.

   sat 95% on PSV 10/5 50% ABG 7.48/49/99.  Obese M, intermittent
   agitation on vent, unable to follow commands. Coarse BS, tachy, RR.
   Distended abdomen, +BS, 2+ LE/dep edema. Labs notable for WBC 11.5
   (13)K, HCT stable, K+ 3.9, Cr 0.7. LFTs trending down.
   No new film today.
   64 yo M with complicated course, SDH, respiratory failure, fevers, now
   resolved and persistent altered mental status. Agree with plan to
   continue 21 day course linezolid for MRSA VAP.  Now AF, F/u additional
   cx data. Remains vent dependent, continue PS with slow wean to [**6-21**].

   for element of benzo dependence / withdrawal and sedation and attempt
   to wean propofol. Continue keppra for sz prophylaxis; imaging stable
   post SDH / evac, with neurosurg following. Hyponatremia
   improved--monitor. Will continue metoprolol as able. Continue TFs with
   plan for G-tube early next week. Remainder as outlined above.
   Patient is critically ill

The patient's current condition includes hypotension, tachycardia, and altered mental status.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis or medication-induced diuresis. Close monitoring and appropriate fluid resuscitation are necessary to maintain adequate blood pressure.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be caused by multiple factors such as medication-induced sed

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a fall and subsequently developed bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, he had complications such as tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS).

The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and has shown improvement in his fever without the use of Tylenol or ibuprofen. His blood cultures are pending, and sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) cultures have been sent for speciation. The patient will continue on linezolid for a duration of 21 days.

His blood pressure has been low, which may be due to sepsis that is now resolving. Lasix has contributed to the low blood pressure, and fluid resuscitation will be given as needed. His respiratory failure is multifactorial, including pneumonia, pulmonary edema, fluid collection, altered mental status, or a central process. The patient's mental status is likely multifactorial as well, including medications, subdural hematomas, and infection. Neurology does not believe seizures are a likely cause, and the EEG showed severe encephalopathy without focal deficits or seizure activity. The patient's neurologic exam will be monitored, and daily wake

He was admitted to the hospital after falling and subsequently developed bilateral subdural hematomas, which required surgical evacuation. During his hospital stay, he experienced complications such as tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. 3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including pneumonia, pulmonary edema, fluid collection, altered mental status, or a central process. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted with bilateral subdural hematomas (SDH) and now presents with complicated post-admission course. He has significant recurrent fevers, slow improvement in mental status, and persistent fevers in the setting of an indwelling central venous catheter (CVC) with no alternative source identified definitively.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Respiratory Failure:
   - Continue with current management.
   - Stabilize metabolic alkalosis with adequate potassium levels.
   - Utilize diamox for possible aid with diuresis and stabilization of alkalosis.
   - Maintain negative fluid balance with a goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65.
   - Hope to move to wean ventilatory support.

2. SDH:
   - Administer Keppra.
   - Monitor exam.
   - Repeat head CT today.
   - Continue with Versed and move to wean tomorrow when head CT/Picc/PEG are completed.

3. Fever:
   - Change CVL today to peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC).
   - Image right pleural space with ultrasound to consider drainage if fevers not resolved.
   - Continue Linezolid.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure:
   - Impaired airway clearance.
   - Impaired ventilation.

2. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO):
   - Unknown origin fever.
   - Hypothermia.
   - Py

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism who was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a fall. He underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, he developed tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status.

The patient presents with several potential medical complications. These include:

1. Fevers: The patient has had persistent fevers, which are indicative of an ongoing infection. The source of the infection is suspected to be the subclavian line site, which appears infected. Cultures have been obtained, and the patient has been started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including linezolid for MRSA coverage.

2. Hypotension: The patient may have had sepsis, which is now resolving. His mean arterial pressure (MAP) is stable, and medications such as Lasix have contributed to low blood pressure. Fluid resuscitation and careful monitoring of blood pressure are recommended.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, involving pneumonia (PNA), pulmonary edema, fluid collection, altered mental status, and possibly a central process given the head bleed. Bronchoscopy and BAL cultures have shown Staphylococcus aureus, which did not have sensitivities. Weaning off mechanical ventilation and minimizing sedation with propofol/fentanyl are recommended. Nebulizers and suctioning should also be continued.

4. Mental status: The patient's mental status is likely multifactorial, including medications, subdurals, infection, and possibly increased intracranial pressure. Neurology does not believe seizures are the cause, and lumbar puncture did not show any organisms or suggest meningitis. EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both cortical and subcortical structures. Holding and weaning sedating medications with daily wake-up calls are advised, along with monitoring neuro exams.

5. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis, for which diamox has been prescribed. Monitoring ABGs and repleting potassium to 4.5 are recommended.

6. Elevated liver function tests (LFTs): The cause of elevated LFTs is unclear, and Tylenol levels are negative. Trending LFTs and monitoring for improvement are advised.

7. Hypertriglyceridemia: This is likely due to propofol, and propofol should be discontinued.

8. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be related to infection/fevers or a central process. Monitoring on telemetry and continuing metoprolol with additional doses as needed are recommended.

9. Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow the patient's subdural hematomas, which appear improved/stable from prior imaging

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted with bilateral sub-dural hematoma and now experiencing a prolonged hospital course complicated by recurrent and persistent fevers. The patient's sedation has been minimized to allow for reasonable evaluation of recovery. There is concern over a possible left sub-clinical source of infection, but technical difficulties have prevented alternative access.

The patient's respiratory failure has improved metabolic alkalosis, and despite fevers, there is minimal evidence of worsening pulmonary infiltrates. The patient's respiratory rate is above the set rate on the ventilator, and an attempt will be made to wean off ventilatory support.

The patient's sub-dural hematoma requires daily wake-up with sedation discontinuation to evaluate mental status. The patient's fever may be due to various sources, including ventilator-associated pneumonia, Clostridium difficile infection, urinary tract infection, or sinusitis. A line change, blood cultures, and additional tests will be conducted to identify the source of the fever.

The patient's nutrition plan involves moving to place a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube through General Surgery given concern for long-term feeds and inability for intraprocedural (IP) completion of the procedure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure
2. Sub-dural hematoma
3. Fever of unknown origin (FUO)
4. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)
5. Cardiac dysrhythmia
6. Sepsis without organ dysfunction

   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.

   persistent fevers and AMS.
   .
   # Fevers: No clear source, had been afebrile for over 48 hours, now
   febrile this AM at 101.4.  Bronch showing Staph Aureus, likely MRSA
   given prior sputums with MRSA.  [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim test was appropriate
   response.  Subclavian line changed yesterday.
   - Follow up cultures including catheter tip from SC line [**2156-12-28**]
   - Linezolid X 21 days (start date = [**12-22**], end date = [**1-12**])
   - will change coverage to include pseudomonas
 Meropenem, Linezolid,
   Levofloxacin
   - continue to follow cultures
   .
   # Hypotension: Pt may have had sepsis which is now resolving.  MAPs
   stable.  Medications (Lasix) contributed to low BP.  No pressors
   necessary at this time.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis, monitor BP
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed. BAL showed Staph Aureus which did not
   have sensitivities.
   - Switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP
   - Nebs and suctioning
   - Minimize sedation with propofol/fentanyl, switched to versed 2^nd to
   hyperlipidemia.
   - had gotten diamox for 2 days, alkalosis resolved and will stop this
   now
   # Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.  EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both
   cortical and subcortical structures which  may be due to increased
   intracranial pressure, no focal deficits or seizure activity
   - Follow neurology recs

   wake up.

   - increase Clonazepam to 1mg PO TID
   - decrease Versed with slow taper per neurosurg recs

   - Monitor on tele

   - Continue Keppra for seizure ppx
   .

   .

   monitor blood sugars.  Discussing with family the option of placing PEG

   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a fall and subsequently developed bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, the patient had complications including tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS).

The patient's current condition includes ongoing fevers, hypotension, respiratory failure, and altered mental status. The source of the fever is still unclear, but previous cultures showed Staphylococcus aureus, likely methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The subclavian line has been changed, and the patient is now on a combination of antibiotics including meropenem, linezolid, and levofloxacin to cover for MRSA and pseudomonas.

The patient's hypotension may be related to sepsis, which is now resolving. Lasix is being used for diuresis, and fluid resuscitation is being provided as needed. The respiratory failure is multifactorial, involving pneumonia, pulmonary edema, fluid collection, altered mental status, and possibly a central process. Efforts are being made to wean the patient off mechanical ventilation and decrease FiO2 as tolerated.

The patient's mental status is likely multifactorial, including medications, subdural

   - Nebs and suctioning
   - Minimize sedation with propofol/fentanyl, switched to versed 2^nd to
   hyperlipidemia.
   - Add diamox 50mg [**Hospital1 **] for 2 days
   # Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.  EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both
   cortical and subcortical structures which  may be due to increased
   intracranial pressure, no focal deficits or seizure activity
   - Follow neurology recs
   - Hold and wean as many sedating medications as possible with daily
   wake up.
   -monitor neuro exams
   - increase Clonazepam to 1mg PO TID
   - decrease Versed with slow taper per neurosurg recs
   #Metabolic alkalosis
   -          Diamox 50mg [**Hospital1 **] x2 days
   -          Monitor abgs
   -          Replete K+ to 4.5
   # Elevated LFTs: RUQ U/S normal without hepatic abscess.  Tylenol
   levels negative.  Unclear etiology.  Slightly lower yesterday.
   -          Continue to trend LFTs, now normal
   # hypertrigliceridemia: likely due to propofol. TG improved to 558
   - propofol d/c
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   - Monitor on tele
   - Continue metoprolol and give more prn
   .
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.  Appear
   improved/stable from prior imaging.
   - Continue Keppra for seizure ppx
   .
   # Hyponatremia:  low normal range. Could have SIADH picture from
   subdural hematomas.
   - Continue to monitor
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # HTN: currently normotensive/hypotensive.
   -          Lasix, Metoprolol as tolerated by BP
   -          Diamox 50mg [**Hospital1 **] for 2 days
   .
   # F: Diurese with a goal of neg 0.5-1 L over the day.
      E: Replete PRN, want K+ to 4.5
      N: On tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control,
   monitor blood sugars.  Discussing with family the option of placing PEG
   tube on Tuesday. Need to discuss with family.
   .
   # PPX: Heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care, Ranitidine,
   bowel regimen.
   .
   # Access: Aline 11/4/008, L subclavian inserted [**2156-12-28**] (old R
   subclavian pulled
 was in [**2159-12-21**])
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a fall and underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, he developed a tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS). 

The patient has been febrile with temperatures ranging from 36.9 to 38.7 degrees Celsius. He has shown signs of hypotension with blood pressure readings as low as 105/51 mmHg. His respiratory status has been critical, requiring mechanical ventilation. The patient's arterial blood gases indicate respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.39 and hypoxemia with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 196.

Physical examination reveals an overweight/obese appearance, small but reactive pupils, midline trachea, and distant heart sounds. Chest auscultation shows rhonchi bilaterally. The patient's extremities are cool and clammy. Neurologic examination shows sedation and no focal deficits or seizure activity. 

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14.2 K/uL, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, and positive cultures for Staphylococcus aureus, likely methicillin-resistant Staphy

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with sub-dural hematomas, respiratory failure, and fever. He is currently sedated and unable to provide a history. The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has had multiple changes in his central venous line due to fevers and bandemia. He is receiving various medications, including antibiotics for possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), diuretics for fluid balance, and sedatives for neuromuscular weakness. The patient's respiratory failure is attributed to a combination of chest wall restriction, neuromuscular weakness, and persistent pulmonary infection. His fever is being treated with multiple antibiotics. The patient's sub-dural hematoma is being monitored, and sedation is being weaned slowly. The patient's mental status is altered, and regular neuro exams are being performed.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to continued ventilatory requirements, limited success in weaning from PSV (pressure support ventilation), chest wall restriction, neuromuscular weakness, and persistent pulmonary infection.
2. Sub-Dural Hematoma: The patient's sub-dural hematoma could lead to increased intracranial pressure, neurological deficits, or seizures if not managed appropriately.
3. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient's persistent fever may indicate an ongoing infection or inflammatory process, which requires further investigation to identify the underlying cause.

   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.

   .

 Meropenem, Linezolid,

   .

   stable.  Medications (Lasix) contributed to low BP.  No pressors
   necessary at this time.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis, monitor BP
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism, who was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a fall. He underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, he developed a tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status.

24-hour events include discontinuation of levoquin, initiation of meropenem, administration of 1700cc diuresis, removal of arterial line due to erythema, three episodes of hypotension (MAPs above 60) with administration of 3 x 250cc normal saline boluses and discontinuation of lasix drip, tachycardia improving with lopressor, replenishment of calcium, and a negative diuresis of -900cc.

The patient has been febrile for over 48 hours, with a temperature of 101.4 this morning. A bronch showed Staphylococcus aureus, likely MRSA given prior sputums with MRSA. The subclavian line was changed yesterday. Cultures including the catheter tip from the SC line were obtained on [**2156-12-28**].

- Hospitalization has been complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure.
- The patient was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS).
- The patient continues to have no clear source of fever, with low-grade fevers at 100°F. Bronchial alveolar lavage (BAL) showed Staphylococcus aureus, likely methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
- Subclavian line was changed, and the tip culture showed no growth.
- The patient's blood cultures showed an increase in white blood cell count (WBC), elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and elevated procalcitonin levels, indicating a possible bacterial infection.
- The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis showed a normal pH, elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), and decreased partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2), indicating respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia.
- The patient's physical examination revealed distant heart sounds, symmetrical chest expansion, rhonchi bilaterally, soft abdomen with bowel sounds present, and no cyanosis or clubbing.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted with bilateral subdural hematoma and now experiencing prolonged respiratory failure, volume overload, and concern for recurrent blood stream infection. The patient has been sedated but is showing increasing responsiveness. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has persistent respiratory failure with volume overload and fever, which may indicate infection with secretions. This could lead to worsening respiratory distress and potentially ventilator-associated pneumonia.
2. Sub-Dural Hematoma: The patient has intermittent agitation, and there is a need to monitor for any changes in basic exam. There is a risk of increased intracranial pressure and further neurological deterioration.
3. Fever: The likely source of the fever is pulmonary, possibly ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient is at risk of developing sepsis or septic shock.
4. Hypotension: The patient has persistent hypotension, which may require careful management to maintain adequate organ perfusion.
5. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient has imbalances in electrolytes and fluids, which can affect various organ functions and overall health.
6. Impaired Airway Clearance: The patient has impaired airway clearance, which can lead to complications such as aspiration pneumonia.
7. Impaired Arousal, Attention, and Cognition: The patient's mental status is impaired, making it difficult to assess the underlying cause and manage potential complications.
8. Impaired Balance and Motor Function:

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   Transferred to the MICU service, in order to further evaluate
   persistent fevers and AMS.
   .
   # Fevers: Causes for fever include PNA given sputum and BAL results and
   now C. Diff positive.  Bronch showing Staph Aureus, likely MRSA given
   prior sputums with MRSA.  [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim test was appropriate response.
   Subclavian line changed, tip culture with no growth.
   - continue Linezolid X 21 days (start date = [**12-22**], end date = [**1-12**])
   with Meropenem to cover pseudomonas and IV Flagyl
   - start PO vanco today for C. Diff, continue IV Flagyl
   - continue to follow cultures
   .
   # Hypotension: Pt may have had sepsis which is now resolving.  MAPs
   stable.  Medications (Lasix) contributed to low BP.  No pressors
   necessary.  Urine output good.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis, monitor BP
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed. BAL showed Staph Aureus which did not
   have sensitivities.
   - Switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP, goal -1 today
   - Nebs and suctioning
   - Minimize sedation with propofol/fentanyl, switched to versed 2^nd to
   hyperlipidemia.
   - wean versed slowly
   # Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.  EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both
   cortical and subcortical structures which  may be due to increased
   intracranial pressure, no focal deficits or seizure activity
   - Follow neurology recs
   - Hold and wean as many sedating medications as possible with daily
   wake up.
   -monitor neuro exams
   - increase Clonazepam to 1mg PO TID
   - use Seroquel for agitation, increase dose today
   - decrease Versed with slow taper per neurosurg recs
     .
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   - Monitor on tele
   - Continue metoprolol and give more prn
   .
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.  Appear
   improved/stable from prior imaging.
   - Continue Keppra for seizure ppx
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # F: Diurese with a goal of neg -1 L over the day.
      E: Replete PRN
      N: On tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control,
   monitor blood sugars.  PEG tube when afebrile X 24 hours.
   .
   # PPX: Heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care, Ranitidine,
   bowel regimen.
   .
   # Access: Aline 11/4/008, R subclavian inserted [**2156-12-28**] (old L
   subclavian pulled
 was in [**2159-12-21**])
   .
   # Code Status: Full
   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a fall and underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, he developed tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status.

The patient has been diagnosed with Clostridium difficile infection (C. Diff positive), bronchopneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus (likely MRSA), and pseudomonal infection. He is currently on multiple antibiotics including linezolid, meropenem, and vancomycin for C. Diff. The patient's blood cultures have shown no growth, and his subclavian line was changed.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.3 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 126 beats per minute, blood pressure of 128/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly decreased hemoglobin levels, and normal platelet count. His kidney function is within normal limits, but his liver enzymes are slightly elevated. Other lab values, including electrolytes, glucose, and cardiac markers, are within normal

Efforts have been made to decrease sedation to allow for mental status evaluation. The patient has recurrent fevers, and multiple sources have been considered. These include C. Difficile infection, sinusitis, and possible catheter-related bloodstream infection. The patient is currently experiencing respiratory failure, fever, and subdural hematoma.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on CPAP/PSV mode with a VT of 899 mL, PS of 14 cmH2O, RR of 14, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 205. These settings suggest that the patient may have difficulty maintaining adequate oxygenation and ventilation. Weaning from mechanical ventilation should be done cautiously to prevent further respiratory failure.

2. C. Difficile Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with C. Difficile infection. Treatment includes antibiotics such as linezolid, meropenem, and metronidazole. It is important to monitor for symptoms of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, abdominal pain, and changes in bowel habits. Adequate hand hygiene and appropriate use of antibiotics can help prevent the spread of this infection.

   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   Transferred to the MICU service, in order to further evaluate
   persistent fevers and AMS.
   .
   # Fevers: Causes for fever include PNA given sputum and BAL results and
   now C. Diff positive.  Bronch showing Staph Aureus, likely MRSA given
   prior sputums with MRSA.  [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim test was appropriate response.
   Subclavian line changed, tip culture with no growth.
   - continue Linezolid X 21 days (start date = [**12-22**], end date = [**1-12**])
   with Meropenem to cover pseudomonas and IV Flagyl
   - Continue PO vanco today for C. Diff, Continue IV Flagyl
   - continue to follow cultures
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed. BAL showed Staph Aureus which did not
   have sensitivities.
   - Switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease pressure support as
   possible
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP, goal negative today
   - Nebs and suctioning
   - wean versed slowly
   .# Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.  EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both
   cortical and subcortical structures which  may be due to increased
   intracranial pressure, no focal deficits or seizure activity. MS
   improving as sedation is weaned.
   - Follow neurology recs
 should re-eval once patient is extubated
   - Hold and wean as many sedating medications as possible with daily
   wake up.
   - monitor neuro exams
   - increase Clonazepam to 1mg PO TID
   - use Seroquel for agitation
   - decrease Versed with slow taper per neurosurg recs
   # Hypotension: Pt may have had sepsis which is now resolving.  MAPs
   stable.  Medications (Lasix) contributed to low BP.  No pressors
   necessary.  Urine output good.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis, monitor BP
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   - Monitor on tele
   - Review chart, consult cardiology if not already consulted
   - increase metroprolol dose to 75mg TID
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.  Appear
   improved/stable from prior imaging.
   - Continue Keppra for seizure ppx
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine.
   # F: Diurese with a goal of negative over the day.

These complications include tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. The patient underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. The hospitalization has been complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. The patient was transferred to the MICU service to further evaluate persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate of 136 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 144/80 mmHg to 159/99 mmHg, respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's weight is 116.3 kg, and height is 67 inches.

The patient has been receiving multiple medications including linezolid, metronidazole, meropenem, and oral vancomycin. He is also on infusions of furosemide, midazolam, and fentanyl. The patient's allergies include ampicillin.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and platelet count within normal range. The creatinine level is decreasing over time, and blood glucose levels are within normal range. Other lab results indicate positive C.

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism who was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status. The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure and has undergone multiple procedures, including evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas, tracheostomy, and placement of a subclavian line. The patient's condition has been complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers, and infection, leading to the need for antibiotic therapy and source control measures.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be attributed to pneumonia (PNA) caused by MRSA, as indicated by positive sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) results. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with pressure support ventilation (PSV) to assist with breathing. Close monitoring and weaning off the ventilator will be necessary to prevent further complications.

2. Infection: The patient has developed a Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection, as evidenced by a positive stool test. Appropriate antibiotic therapy should be continued to treat the infection and prevent its spread. Source control measures should also be implemented to minimize the risk of further infections.

3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, which is now resolving. Fluid resuscitation and diuretic therapy with Lasix may be required to manage fluid balance

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism, who was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a fall. The patient underwent an evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas. During hospitalization, the patient developed tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. The patient was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS).

Assessment and Plan:
1. Fevers: The patient has been experiencing fevers, which have been attributed to pneumonia (PNA), positive C. diff, and Staph Aureus (likely MRSA) in the bronch. The subclavian line was changed, and the tip culture showed no growth. The plan is to continue Linezolid for 21 days, switch to PO vancomycin for C. diff, and continue IV Flagyl. Cultures will be monitored.
2. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure may have been due to sepsis, which is now resolving. Medications (Lasix) contributed to the low BP. No pressors are necessary, and urine output is good. PRN fluids will be given for volume resuscitation, and Lasix will be continued for diuresis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be multifactorial, including PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid collection, altered mental status, or a central process. BAL

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism who underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas following a fall. He has been hospitalized with complications including tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has persistent fevers and positive cultures for C. difficile and MRSA, indicating a possible infection. The causes of fever include pneumonia given sputum and BAL results.
2. Hypotension: The patient may have had sepsis, which is now resolving. Medications (Lasix) contributed to low blood pressure. MAPs are stable, and no pressors are necessary. Urine output is good.
3. Respiratory Failure: Multifactorial causes include pneumonia, pulmonary edema, fluid collection, secondary to altered mental status or even a central process given the head bleed. BAL showed Staph Aureus, which did not have sensitivities.
4. Mental Status: Multifactorial causes include medications, subdurals, infection, all contributing to altered mental status. Neurology does not feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or suggest any meningitis.
5. Tachycardia: Likely related to infection/fevers but could also be from a central process, agitation, or pain.

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   Transferred to the MICU service, in order to further evaluate
   persistent fevers and AMS.
   .
   # Fevers: Causes for fever include PNA given sputum and BAL results and
   now C. Diff positive.  Bronch showing Staph Aureus, likely MRSA given
   prior sputums with MRSA.  [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim test was appropriate response.
   Subclavian line changed, tip culture with no growth.
   - continue Linezolid X 21 days (start date = [**12-22**], end date = [**1-12**])
   with Meropenem to cover pseudomonas and IV Flagyl
   - start PO vanco today for C. Diff, continue IV Flagyl
   - continue to follow cultures
   .
   # Hypotension: Pt may have had sepsis which is now resolving.  MAPs
   stable.  Medications (Lasix) contributed to low BP.  No pressors
   necessary.  Urine output good.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis, monitor BP
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed. BAL showed Staph Aureus which did not
   have sensitivities.
   - Switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease FiO2 as tolerated
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP, goal -1 today
   - Nebs and suctioning
   - Minimize sedation with propofol/fentanyl, switched to versed 2^nd to
   hyperlipidemia.
   - wean versed slowly
   # Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.  EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both
   cortical and subcortical structures which  may be due to increased
   intracranial pressure, no focal deficits or seizure activity
   - Follow neurology recs
   - Hold and wean as many sedating medications as possible with daily
   wake up.
   -monitor neuro exams
   - increase Clonazepam to 1mg PO TID
   - use Seroquel for agitation, increase dose today
   - decrease Versed with slow taper per neurosurg recs
     .
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   - Monitor on tele
   - Continue metoprolol and give more prn
   .
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.  Appear
   improved/stable from prior imaging.
   - Continue Keppra for seizure ppx
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # F: Diurese with a goal of neg -1 L over the day.
      E: Replete PRN
      N: On tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control,
   monitor blood sugars.  PEG tube when afebrile X 24 hours.
   .
   # PPX: Heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care, Ranitidine,
   bowel regimen.
   .
   # Access: Aline 11/4/008, R subclavian inserted [**2156-12-28**] (old L
   subclavian pulled
 was in [**2159-12-21**])
   .
   # Code Status: Full
   .

During his hospitalization, he developed a tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS).

The patient has been diagnosed with several conditions:

Additionally, he tested positive for Clostridium difficile (C. Diff) infection. The causative organism for his respiratory infection is Staphylococcus aureus, which is likely methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
2. Hypotension: The patient may have had sepsis, which is now resolving. His mean arterial pressure (MAP) is stable, and medications such as furosemide (Lasix) contributed to low blood pressure. No pressors are necessary, and his urine output is good.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including pneumonia, pulmonary edema, fluid collection, altered mental status, or a central process given the head bleed. The BAL showed Staphylococcus

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with an initial admission for bilateral sub-dural hematoma. He has had a prolonged hospital course with slow improvement in mental status. The patient has been experiencing recurrent fevers, and multiple sources have been considered. It appears that C. Diff, sinusitis, and possible catheter-related blood stream infection have all been likely contributing factors.

The patient's current conditions include respiratory failure, fever of unknown origin, obstructive sleep apnea, subdural hemorrhage, cardiac dysrhythmia, chronic respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and agitation.

The plan includes continuing with pressure support ventilation (PSV) wean, considering PEEP wean in the setting of negative fluid balance. The patient is being treated for sinusitis and C. Diff, with plans to complete a course of antibiotics for both. Pneumonia is a concern but there have been minimal changes in pulmonary infiltrates, so the treatment will be completed.

The patient is also being monitored for SVT (supraventricular tachycardia) and is on beta blockers. The plan is to uptitrate the beta blocker and review old records for apparent cardiac consultation. For the subdural hematoma, sedation wean is expected, with plans to titrate fentanyl down to 75 today and use Seroquel as the primary medication for agitation.

Neuro and neurosurgery support is appreciated in considering the treatment plan. Additional plans are

   Assessment and Plan
   64 yo M with PMH of HTN, hypothyroidism who is s/p evacuation of
   bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall. Hospitalization has been
   complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers and respiratory failure.
   Transferred to the MICU service, in order to further evaluate
   persistent fevers and AMS.
   .
   # Fevers: Causes for fever include PNA given sputum and BAL results and
   now C. Diff positive.  Bronch showing Staph Aureus, likely MRSA given
   prior sputums with MRSA.  [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim test was appropriate response.
   Subclavian line changed, tip culture with no growth.
   - continue Linezolid X 21 days (start date = [**12-22**], end date = [**1-12**])
   with Meropenem to cover pseudomonas and IV Flagyl
   - Continue PO vanco today for C. Diff, Continue IV Flagyl
   - continue to follow cultures
   # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid
   collection, also secondary to altered mental status or even a central
   process given the head bleed. BAL showed Staph Aureus which did not
   have sensitivities.
   - Switch to PS to attempt to wean, decrease pressure support as
   possible
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis as tolerated by BP, goal negative today
   - Nebs and suctioning
   - wean versed slowly
   .# Mental status: likely multifactorial including medications,
   subdurals, infection all are likely contributing. Neurology does not
   feel seizures are likely cause. LP did not show any organisms or
   suggest any meningitis.  EEG showed severe encephalopathy of both
   cortical and subcortical structures which  may be due to increased
   intracranial pressure, no focal deficits or seizure activity. MS
   improving as sedation is weaned.
   - Follow neurology recs
 should re-eval once patient is extubated
   - Hold and wean as many sedating medications as possible with daily
   wake up.
   - monitor neuro exams
   - increase Clonazepam to 1mg PO TID
   - use Seroquel for agitation
   - decrease Versed with slow taper per neurosurg recs
   # Hypotension: Pt may have had sepsis which is now resolving.  MAPs
   stable.  Medications (Lasix) contributed to low BP.  No pressors
   necessary.  Urine output good.
   - PRN fluids for volume resuscitation
   - Lasix gtt for diuresis, monitor BP
   # Tachycardia: likely related to infection/fevers but could also be
   from a central process, agitation or pain.
   - Monitor on tele
   - Review chart, consult cardiology if not already consulted
   - increase metroprolol dose to 75mg TID
   # Subdural hematomas: Neurosurgery will continue to follow.  Appear
   improved/stable from prior imaging.
   - Continue Keppra for seizure ppx
   # Hypothyroidism: continue levothyroxine.
   # F: Diurese with a goal of negative over the day.
      E: Replete PRN
      N: On tube feeds to goal. Continue insulin SS for glycemic control,
   monitor blood sugars.  PEG tube when afebrile X 24 hours.
   # PPX: Heparin SQ for DVT ppx, chlorhexidine mouth care, Ranitidine,
   bowel regimen.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the hospital after falling and subsequently developed bilateral subdural hematomas. During his hospitalization, he experienced tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status.

Medical Complications:
1. Fevers: The patient has had persistent fevers, which have been attributed to pneumonia (PNA) with sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) results showing Staphylococcus aureus, likely methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). He also tested positive for Clostridium difficile (C. diff). His subclavian line was changed, and the tip culture showed no growth.

2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including PNA, pulmonary edema, fluid collection, and secondary to altered mental status or a central process due to the head bleed. BAL showed Staph aureus, which did not have sensitivities.

3. Mental Status: The patient's mental status is likely multifactorial, including medications, subdural hematomas, and infection. Neurology does not believe seizures are the cause. A lumbar puncture (LP) did not show any organisms or suggest meningitis. An electroencephalogram

Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism, who presented to the hospital with bilateral subdural hematomas following a fall. His hospitalization has been complicated by a tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to the MICU service for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status (AMS).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure of 155/34 mmHg, respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on a tracheostomy tube with CPAP/PSV ventilation. The patient appears to be tachycardic and has had episodes of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT).

The patient's physical examination reveals distant heart sounds, tachycardia without murmurs, rhonchorous breath sounds bilaterally, soft abdomen with bowel sounds present, and no extremity edema or cyanosis. Neurologically, the patient is awake, alert, and responsive, following simple commands, and moves all four extremities spontaneously.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated platelet count, normal creatinine, slightly low potassium, and normal liver function tests. The patient is positive for C. difficile toxin and Staphylococcus aure

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with an initial admission for bilateral sub-dural hematoma. He has had a prolonged hospital course with slow improvement in mental status. The patient's chief complaint is respiratory distress, and he is currently in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia with episodes rising to the 160s, blood pressure within normal range, respiratory rate slightly elevated, and oxygen saturation at 98%. The patient's physical examination reveals that he is alert but slightly agitated, with chest findings of congestive heart failure (CTA) and abdominal findings of obesity and distension. There are no edema in the extremities.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), slightly decreased hemoglobin (Hct), normal platelet count (Plt), and normal creatinine (Cr). Other lab values are within normal limits or do not show significant abnormalities.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on CPAP/PSV mode of ventilation, and plans are to continue weaning as tolerated. In the setting of a negative fluid balance, the plan is to consider PEEP wean.

2. Fever: The patient has recurrent fevers, and multiple sources have been considered. C. Difficile infection, sinusitis, and possible catheter-related blood stream infection have all been treated. C. Difficile infection has been treated with Flag

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's chief complaint is respiratory distress. The patient has been experiencing tachycardia with episodes rising to 160's, more alertness but also increased agitation, and difficulty with balance and impaired motor function. The patient is currently on ventilatory support and has a tracheostomy tube in place.

The vital signs show a temperature of 37.7°C, blood pressure ranging from 134/81 mmHg to 155/87 mmHg, heart rate between 102-134 bpm, respiratory rate of 10-26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%.

The patient's fluid balance indicates an intake of 3,144 mL and output of 4,060 mL since 12 AM. The weight is currently 116.3 kg, with a height of 67 inches.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and C-reactive protein (CRP), decreased hemoglobin (Hgb) and hematocrit (Hct), elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests.

The patient has been diagnosed with Clostridium difficile infection, electrolyte and fluid disorder, hypotension, impaired airway clearance, impaired arousal, attention, and cognition, impaired balance, impaired motor function, impaired ventilation, anxiety, tachycardia, fever of unknown origin, obstructive sleep apnea, subdural

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 64-year-old male with initial admission of bilateral sub-dural hematoma.
- He has had a prolonged hospital course with slow improvement in mental status.
- Efforts have been made to decrease sedation to allow for mental status evaluation.
- The patient has recurrent fevers, with multiple sources considered and treated (C. Diff, sinusitis, possible catheter-related blood stream infection).
- Respiratory failure is present but appears to be improving with the patient being more alert and consistently negative.
- The patient is being prepared for a trial of spontaneous breathing tests (SBT) and short tracheostomy collar sprints.
- Fever is overall down.
- C. Diff is being treated with Flagyl for 2 weeks after discontinuing all antibiotics.
- Sinusitis treatment includes Afrin for Rx and continued antibiotics.
- Pneumonia is a concern, but there has been minimal change in pulmonary infiltrates and treatment will be completed.
- Linezolid/Meropenem are being used.
- SVT (supraventricular tachycardia) is present and requires up titration of beta-blocker.
- Sub-dural hematoma is expected to have sedation weaned off, with a plan to titrate fentanyl down to 50 today and use Seroquel as primary [**Doctor Last Name**] for agitation.
- Additional plans are defined in the housestaff note.
- ICU care includes nutrition

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. He was admitted to the ICU for further evaluation of persistent fevers and altered mental status following a fall that resulted in bilateral subdural hematomas. The patient's hospitalization has been complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 139 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 102/62 to 146/101 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, set at a pressure support of 5 cmH2O, peak inspiratory pressure of 11 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and C-reactive protein (CRP), indicating an ongoing infection. Blood cultures have been sent. The patient is positive for Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection and has been treated with oral vancomycin. Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) was identified in bronchoscopic samples, and the patient is being treated with linezolid, meropenem, and intravenous Flagyl.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. He has been diagnosed with bilateral sub-dural hematomas and is currently in the ICU. The patient's alertness has improved while undergoing sedation weaning and has the capacity to wean off ventilator support. 

The patient's current conditions include respiratory failure, sub-dural hematoma, and altered mental status. The respiratory failure is being managed with tracheostomy mask trials, pressure support ventilation (PSV), and plans for 2-hour trials of spontaneous breathing twice a day. The sub-dural hematoma is being managed with minimizing sedating medications and supportive care. The altered mental status is likely due to a combination of factors including the underlying hematoma insult, active infection, and paradoxical effects of sedating medications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1) Respiratory Failure - The patient may experience further respiratory distress or difficulty weaning off the ventilator support.
2) Sub-Dural Hematoma - There is a risk of increased intracranial pressure or neurological deterioration due to the hematoma.
3) Altered Mental Status - The patient may continue to have confusion or cognitive impairment.
4) HEMATEMESIS (Upper GI Bleed, UGIB) - There is a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism who has been admitted to the ICU. He underwent evacuation of bilateral subdural hematomas after a fall and his hospitalization has been complicated by tension pneumothorax, fevers, and respiratory failure. The patient is currently being treated for MRSA and Acinetobacter infections in the sputum. 

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including pneumonia (PNA), pulmonary edema, fluid collection, and secondary to altered mental status or a central process given the head bleed. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy with CPAP/PSV mode.

The patient's mental status is likely multifactorial, including medications, subdural hematomas, infection, and other factors. Neurology does not feel seizures are the likely cause. The patient underwent a lumbar puncture (LP) that did not show any organisms or suggest any meningitis. An electroencephalogram (EEG) showed severe encephalopathy of both cortical and subcortical structures, which may be due to increased intracranial pressure, without focal deficits or seizure activity. The patient's mental status is improving as sedation is weaned. The patient is now receiving lorazepam (Ativan) PRN for agitation and will need to adjust medications for better control on fewer agents. A psych consultation
